review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
In space no one can hear you scream, but my neighbors still knocked at my door to ask why I was so frustrated.

There are bad games, and then there are things that are not even games. This is not a game. It's an unpolished attempt at a game.

The "game" throws you into space without any information, interface, or training. And then just randomly punishes you with defeat screens, for the most absurd/unforgiving/unfun reasons. There is no learning curve - you hardly get any better by playing it again. There's just guesswork and dumb repetition once you found a strategy that, for some unknown reason, works. Save your time and money and, I don't know, go watch clouds move in the sky, or flowers grow, or ants collect food. All of those activities are more entertaining than this "game"

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1614482629}
review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 3.4h (based on Steam, 14/15 levels completed)

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Forbidden Planet[/b] is a tower defense game in a space setting. You'll mine resources, prevent asteroid attacks, and complete your mission.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 15 levels to play
- 4 mission types

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Confusing tutorial
- Some visuals stutter when you fast forward in the middle of an attack
- Most levels can be done with the same strategy with a lot of waiting time to finish the level
- Your purchased objects will not show up even though you already spend your money if you fast forward the game
- No map or radar to detect where you are supposed to go
- Most purchasable objects are useless

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]No.[/b]
[i]I believe there are better tower defense games out there.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
The game does a good job depicting the game in a space setting. You'll see a machinery-like main ship that is located in the middle of the level, along with planets and asteroids that are scattered around it. I didn't recognize the planets, which might be either because they are made-up planets or uncommon ones. They fit well with the space background though - it's as if they are actual planet images except for the glowing effect and machinery objects that will show up if you build something to it.

The interface is one of the greatest flaws in the game. The fast forward button looks like slapped into the already existing pause button, making them look weird when you see them next to each other. The purchase button is also placed in a very weird spot that you won't be able to tell where it is if you didn't play the tutorial beforehand. The same goes for the purchasing menu - it doesn't look informative unless you know what to do.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2410193626 

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay is simpler compared to other tower defense games. You can purchase various objects from the base, whether it's [i]Probe[/i]s for colonizing a planet for its resources, [i]Turrel[/i]s that act as a turret to shoot down meteoroids, or others. The game will revolve around gathering resources from colonized planets and purchasing other objects, mostly [i]Turrel[/i]s, to avoid being destroyed by the meteoroids.

Different missions are available across 15 levels, excluding the tutorial. Most missions are similar, whether it's gathering a certain amount of resources, surviving a certain number of waves, destroying all asteroids, or escorting a spaceship. The latter two might be a bit tricky since you need to travel around with limited resources to finish the missions. However, I found that the escorting mission to be a bit weird since I tend not to see the spaceship when I left it alone, leading me to think that the game was still running even though I failed to protect the ship.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2410194400 

Despite the varying missions, most levels can be done with the same strategy: find a planet to colonize and put some [i]Turrel[/i]s in it. Although you'll be busy setting these up at the beginning, it doesn't take long before it becomes a waiting game - you'll need to fast forward the game and wait for several minutes until the mission objective is completed. To be honest, I failed the level more often because I was either running out of bounds due to my boredom or forgot to buy fuel for my ship rather than failing the mission objective.

Most attacking objects are useless. Although I have been talking about [i]Turrel[/i]s most of the time as a means to attacking, there are other objects that you can purchase. However, they are only temporary, meaning that they will be gone after a few seconds. The expensive price of these items also doesn't help to make them worthwhile, especially since you only need to place 2 [i]Turrel[/i]s on each planet to deal with most asteroids.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2410196326 

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game at 3.4h. My playtime on Steam is higher than this since I did some idling of the game a few years ago. The difficulty is surprisingly easy once you know what to do except for one level. There is one level where you need to collect a lot of resources within a time limit with only 2 planets to colonize. Since you'll end up having to rely on RNG for this, I didn't bother to finish this level. Some missions such as the escorting missions will require you to think of a strategy to use your resources effectively, but you won't need to think too much compared to other tower defense games.

[b]Problems[/b]
There is no map or radar on screen. You'll spend most of your time locating planets or asteroids because of this. The game also seems not to process my purchase if I bought items with the fast-forward button on. Lastly, although I still could move normally, the visual will stutter sometimes whenever there's a meteoroid attack when I turned the fast-forward button on.

[h3]Specs[/h3]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
The game doesn't feel like a tower defense game at all. For one, the difficulty is very easy except for one level that relies on RNG. The confusing tutorial also doesn't help me to understand the game at the beginning, making most of the difficulties that I went through to be spent on learning how the game works. It's not surprising why the game isn't being sold anymore due to the state it's in.

Forbidden Planet is a fairly regular game, but for its value it is very complex. A lot of people said they could not understand it, but it's not that difficult: you buy a probe, colonize a planet, withdraw resources from it, buy defenses for this planet and your base. It is also necessary to fuel the ship, to upgrades it  and finally to resist the rain of asteroids (this part is the real challenge of the game, the rest is just preparation). Pretty boring right? But that's exactly what they announced, and everything worked without bugs here. It's not my kind of game, but it's good to waste few minutes.

review:
Tags: Tower Defense
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content - Remove from library

TLDR: Poorly executed. Easy to upgrade yourself in an unwinnable corner. Constant re-use of assets. Some design in mechanics make no sense because pacing makes them irrelevant.

What might at first seem like an intriguing proposition : Colonize planet, set up shuttle trading network , get cash, put guns around space, ugrade ship, take down asteroids quickly becomes a chore. The same mechanic / map is reused each time with a slightly increasing difficulty in the mission complete objective, not much point in colonize the planets since they get blown to smithereens rather easily, your ship cant shoot so you cant actively defend them, and while you are out collecting ressources you cannot keep an eye on whats going on with your ressource gathering nodes. The asteroids spawn about randomly so you can put yourself in a situation where you didnt keep enough money for refuel after upgrading and cant find an asteroid giving you a game over. It just has so little entertainment value and joy to offer and so much chore and repetition, the game looks underwhelming, with arial font tacked on top of jpeg space. This would had worked better 30 years ago as an atari game or something, and maybe now people would have nostalgia and would want to see it being remade. But as things stand the concept is too primitive to be worth the attention in this day and age

The Evil Lord has set up a system of defences on the Forbidden Planet, to help him return to power. It is your job to destroy them, skimming the planet's surface and blasting them out. Forbidden Planet is viewed form the cockpit of your craft, with the action displayed in vector graphics. You must shoot out Anti-Aircraft towers and guided missiles for points, while avoiding the damage they can inflict. As well as controls, options include limiting some of the sound effects, and arranging the in-game display in 3 different ways.

Forbidden Planet's a pace racing, addictive game - shame it crashed when I was just beginning to clock up a reasonable score!
